title: Using macros 2.0 single-matcher shorthand with `macro_rules!` results in an invalid suggestion

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: A-parser
labels.description: Area: The parsing of Rust source code to an AST.

labels.name: A-macros
labels.description: Area: All kinds of macros (custom derive, macro_rules!, proc macros, ..)

labels.name: T-compiler

labels.name: D-invalid-suggestion

body:
Given the following code ([playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=044bfb218a6c674af58d48ab60892f7f)):

```rust
macro_rules! count_tts($($t:tt)*) {
    // TODO
    0
}
```

The current output is:

```
error: macros that expand to items must be delimited with braces or followed by a semicolon
 --> src/lib.rs:1:23
  |
1 | macro_rules! count_tts($($t:tt)*) {
  |                       ^^^^^^^^^^^
  |
help: change the delimiters to curly braces
  |
1 | macro_rules! count_tts{$($t:tt)*} {
  |                       ~         ~
help: add a semicolon
  |
1 | macro_rules! count_tts($($t:tt)*); {
  |                                  +

error: expected item, found `{`
 --> src/lib.rs:1:35
  |
1 | macro_rules! count_tts($($t:tt)*) {
  |                                   ^ expected item
```

Neither of the suggestions in the first diagnostic are valid syntax:
```rust
macro_rules! count_tts { $($t:tt)* } {
    // TODO
    0
}
```

```
error: expected item, found `{`
 --> src/lib.rs:1:38
  |
1 | macro_rules! count_tts { $($t:tt)* } {
  |                                      ^ expected item
```

```rust
macro_rules! count_tts($($t:tt)*); {
    // TODO
    0
}
```

```
error: expected item, found `{`
 --> src/lib.rs:1:36
  |
1 | macro_rules! count_tts($($t:tt)*); {
  |                                    ^ expected item
```

Ideally, the first diagnostic shouldn't appear in this case.

@rustbot modify labels: +A-macros +D-incorrect +D-invalid-suggestion
